author: TomPegden
title: TomPegden published Next Plc boss: Big restrictions on immigration could damage UK
text:
"I believe we should gain some control but we can either try and trade our way out of this mess or we can try and protect ourselves by erecting barriers to trade and movement of people. 
"If we try and protect our way out of this, we are doomed." 
Asked about leave voters potentially feeling betrayed if immigration was not reduced below 100,000 within a few years, he said: "I voted leave and I certainly won't feel betrayed â€“ you only have to go into our hospitals and other services to see the vital role immigrants play in our country." 
He also said Next had no plans to change its investment plans following the outcome of the vote, despite warnings that Brexit was hitting business confidence and investment, and called on Prime Minister Theresa May to make the UK an open, competitive and global economy. 
Despite her recent "Brexit means Brexit" remark, Theresa May has now said Article 50 will only be triggered when there is a UK-wide approach to leaving, and clear objectives for negotiations. 
She is on an official visit to meet Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon in Edinburgh, to set out her commitment to preserving the United Kingdom following the vote. 
Many Scottish people, in particular, are committed to remaining within the European Union.
